facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1962 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1962. Appeal from the

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 2, 1961 of Judicial Commissioners Court at Manipur in Criminal Revision No. 20 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 2, 1961 of the-Judicial Commissioners Court at Manipur in Criminal Revision No. 20 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 29, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: November 29, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The short question of law which arises in this appeal

facts.text: Respondent charged with offence under s. 7 of Essential Commodities Act, 1955 for storing 178 Mds. of paddy on February 9, 1960 without licence violating cl. 3 of Manipur Foodgrains Dealers Licensing Order, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was charged with having companymitted an offernce punishable under s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 in that on February 9 , 1960, he was found storing 178 Mds. of paddy in his godown without any licence in violation of cl. 3 of the said Order.

facts.text: On February 9, 1960, respondent's godown was searched and 178 Mds. of paddy found stored.

anchor.surface_text: The case against the respondent was that on February 9, 1960, his godown was searched and 178 Mds. of paddy was found stored in it.

facts.text: Respondent did not deny the fact of 178 Mds. paddy found in godown.

anchor.surface_text: This fact was number denied by the respondent though he pleaded that the paddy which was found in his godown

facts.text: Respondent pleaded paddy was for consumption of his 15 family members.

anchor.surface_text: was meant for the companysumption of the members of his family who numbered fifteen.

facts.text: Respondent pleaded 40 Mds. of paddy belonged to Lalito Singh, his relation.

anchor.surface_text: He also pleaded that out of the stock found in his godown 40 Mds. of paddy belonged to Lalito Singh, his relation.

facts.text: Sub Divisional Magistrate, Bishanpur tried the case.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sub Divisional Magistrate, Bishanpur, who tried the case of the respondent

facts.text: Trial Magistrate disbelieved respondent's statement that stock was for family consumption.

anchor.surface_text: did number believe his statement that the stock was meant for the companysump- tion of the members of his family.

facts.text: Trial Magistrate believed Lalito Singh's evidence that 40 Mds. belonged to him and ordered release of 40 Mds. to Lalito Singh.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, believed the evidence of Lalito Singh that. 40 Mds. out of the stock belonged to him, and so he passed an order directing that out of the stock which had been attached 40 Mds. should be released in favour of Lalito Singh.

facts.text: Trial Magistrate convicted respondent under s.7 Essential Commodities Act based on presumption under cl. 3(2) attracting cl. 3(1) and cl.7.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the rest of the stock, companyclusion the learned trial Magistrate came to the that as a result of the provisions companytained in cl. 3 2  of the Order a presumption arose against the respondent and that presumption took his case under cl. 3 1  of the Order.

facts.text: Trial Magistrate fined respondent Rs. 500/-, in default 3 months rigorous imprisonment, no forfeiture.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings the learned Magistrate companyvicted the respondent if the offence charged. He, however, held that it was number necessary to direct the forfeiture of the paddy and that the ends of Justice would be met if he was fined to Day Rs. 500/- in default to suffer rigorous imprisonment for three months.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Sessions Judge at Manipur.

anchor.surface_text: Against this Order the respondent preferred an appeal before the learned Sessions Judge at Manipur

facts.text: Sessions Judge upheld Magistrate's view, confirmed conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge substantially agreed the view taken by the learned Magistrate. ... The order of sentence also was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Respondent filed Revision Application before Judicial Commissioner, Manipur, which succeeded.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the Judicial Commissioner, Manipur, by a Revision Application and his Revision Application succeeded.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner acquitted respondent based on judgment in revision applications Nos. 7, 11 and 13 of 1961 dated June 5, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before the present- Revision Application came on for hearing before the learned Judicial Commissioner he had examined the question of law ... pronounced his judgment on June 5, 1961. ... following his earlier decision the learned Judicial Commissioner allowed the respondents Revision Application and set aside the order of companyviction and sentence passed against him.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner held on December 2, 1961 that presumption under cl. 3(2) does not make person a dealer under cl. 3(1).

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 2, 1961 of the-Judicial Commissioners Court at Manipur

facts.text: Manipur Administration appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the Manipur Administration has companye to this Court by special leave

facts.text: Paddy is one of the foodgrains specified in Schedule 1.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that paddy is one of the foodgrains specified in Schedule 1.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Judicial Commissioner's order of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.

facts.text: Stock of paddy had been attached.

anchor.surface_text: out of the stock which had been attached 40 Mds. should be released

issues.text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal relates to the construction of cl. 3(2) of the Manipur Foodgrains Dealers Licensing Order, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal relates to the companystruction of cl. 3 2  of the Manipur Foodgrains Dealers Licensing Order, 1958. This question arises in this way. The respondent was charged with having companymitted an offernce punishable under s. 7 of the Essenti

anchor.surface_text: That is how the only question which falls for our decision in the present appeal is in regard to the companystruction of the said clause. At this stage, it would be companyvenient to refer to the relevant provisions of the Order. Clause 2 a  defines a dealer as meaning a person engaged in the business of purchase, sale or storage for sale, of any one or more of the foodgrains in quantity of one hundred maunds or more at any one time.

issues.text: whether the respondent is guilty under s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, it is necessary to decide whether he can be said to be a dealer within the meaning of cl. 3 of the Order

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the question as to whether the respondent is guilty under s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, it is necessary to decide whether he can be said to be a dealer within the meaning of cl. 3 of the Order. A dealer has been defined by cl. 2 a  and that definition we have already numbericed. The said definition shows that before a person can be said to be a dealer it must be shown that he carries on business of purchase or sale or storage for sale of any of the companymodities specified in the Schedule, and that the sale must be in quantity of 100 mds. or more at any one time.

Therefore, it is urged that it would be defeating the purpose of cl. 3 2  if the view taken by the learned Judicial Commissioner is upheld

arguments.claim: Cl. 3 is penal clause requiring strict construction

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the point raised by Mr. Khanna before us, it is necessary to bear in mind that clause 3 in question ultimately imposes a penalty on the offender and as such, it is in the nature of a penal clause. Therefore, it is necessary that it must be strictly construed.

arguments.claim: 'Dealer' under cl. 2(a) requires carrying on 'business' implying continuity of transactions, not single instance

anchor.surface_text: the concept of business in the context must necessarily postulate continuity of transactions. It is not a single, casual or solitary transaction of sale, purchase or storage that would make a person a dealer. It is only where it is shown that there is a sort of continuity of one or the other of the said transactions that the requirement as to business postulated by the definition would be satisfied.

arguments.claim: Presumption under cl. 3(2) only deems storage for purpose of sale, does not cover 'business' element for cl. 3(1)

anchor.surface_text: What does this presumption amount to? It amounts to this and nothing more that the stock found with a given individual of 100 or more maunds of the specified foodgrains had been stored by him for the purpose of sale. Having reached this conclusion on the strength of the presumption, the prosecution would still have to show that the store of the foodgrains for the purpose of sale thus presumed was made by him for the purpose of carrying on the business

arguments.claim: Prosecution must prove business element by independent evidence after presumption, e.g., multiple storages

anchor.surface_text: The element of business which is essential to attract the provisions of cl. 3 1  is thus not covered by the presumption raised under cl. 3 2 . That part of the case would still have to be proved by the prosecution by other independent evidence. It may be that this part of the case can be proved by the prosecution by showing that store of 100 mds. or more of the foodgrains was found with the said person more than once.

arguments.claim: Paddy storage for family consumption (15 members)

anchor.surface_text: This fact was not denied by the respondent though he pleaded that the paddy which was found in his godown was meant for the consumption of the members of his family who numbered fifteen.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecting that out of the stock which had been attached 40 Mds. should be released

arguments.claim: 40 Mds. paddy belonged to Lalito Singh

anchor.surface_text: He also pleaded that out of the stock found in his godown 40 Mds. of paddy belonged to Lalito Singh, his relation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in favour of Lalito Singh. In regard to the rest of the stock, companyclusion the learned trial Magistrate came to the that as a result of the provis

arguments.court_reasoning: Believed Lalito Singh's evidence, ordered release

arguments.claim: Cl. 3(2) worded to raise limited presumption excluding cultivators with occasional large storage/sale

anchor.surface_text: It appears that cl. 3 2  may have been deliberately worded so as to raise a limited presumption in order to exclude cases of cultivators who may on occasions be in possession of more than 100 mds. of foodgrains grown in their fields.

holdings.text: Clause 3 of the Order is in the nature of a penal clause and must be strictly construed.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the point raised by Mr. Khanna before us, it is necessary to bear in mind that clause 3 in question ultimately imposes a penalty on the offender and as such, it is in the nature of a penal clause. Therefore, it is necessary that it must be strictly construed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 3 imposes penalty on offender, hence penal in nature requiring strict construction.

holdings.text: The deeming provision in cl. 3(2) must have the fiction drawn to the maximum extent legitimately permissible under the words of the clause.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt, as Mr. Khanna has contended, that if cl. 3(2) which is in the nature of a deeming provision provides for a fiction, we ought to draw the fiction to the maximum extent legitimately permissible under the words of the clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed with contention on interpretation of deeming provisions, limited by words used.

holdings.text: A dealer under cl. 2(a) must be engaged in the business of purchase, sale or storage for sale implying continuity of transactions, not a single casual or solitary transaction.

anchor.surface_text: the concept of business in the context must necessarily postulate continuity of transactions. It is not a single, casual or solitary transaction of sale, purchase or storage that would make a person a dealer. It is only where it is shown that there is a sort of continuity of one or the other of the said transactions that the requirement as to business postulated by the definition would be satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition requires 'business' which postulates continuity; single transaction would render word 'business' redundant.

holdings.text: The presumption under cl. 3(2) amounts only to storage for the purpose of sale and nothing more; it does not cover the element of business required for cl. 3(1).

anchor.surface_text: What does this presumption amount to? It amounts to this and nothing more that the stock found with a given individual of 100 or more maunds of the specified foodgrains had been stored by him for the purpose of sale. Having reached this conclusion on the strength of the presumption, the prosecution would still have to show that the store of the foodgrains for the purpose of sale thus presumed was made by him for the purpose of carrying on the business

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict construction limits presumption to express words 'for the purpose of sale'; business element separate under dealer definition.

holdings.text: The prosecution must prove the business element by independent evidence even after the presumption under cl. 3(2) is raised.

anchor.surface_text: The element of business which is essential to attract the provisions of cl. 3(1) is thus not covered by the presumption raised under cl. 3(2). That part of the case would still have to be proved by the prosecution by other independent evidence. It may be that this part of the case can be proved by the prosecution by showing that store of 100 mds. or more of the foodgrains was found with the said person more than once.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption rebuttable and limited; business proof requires additional evidence like multiple storages.

holdings.text: The direct reference in cl. 3(2) to cl. 3(1) does not widen the scope of the presumption beyond storage for purpose of sale.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Khanna contends that in construing the effect of cl. 3(2) we must remember that this clause makes direct reference to cl. 3(1), and that no doubt is true but the fact that cl. 3(2) directly refers to cl. 3(1) does not help to widen the scope of the presumption

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference specifies purpose for presumption, not expands its content.

holdings.text: Courts cannot add words to cl. 3(2); presumption limited by plain words despite policy arguments.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Khanna then urges that if the Legislature had intended that after drawing the presumption about the storage for the purpose of sale, the prosecution should still have to cover some further ground and lead additional evidence to prove that the said store had been made for the purpose of business of storage, then the statutory presumption would really serve no useful purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot rewrite provision; words do not justify presuming business.

holdings.text: Cl. 3(2) raises limited presumption possibly to exclude cultivators with occasional large storage.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that cl. 3(2) may have been deliberately worded so as to raise a limited presumption in order to exclude cases of cultivators who may on occasions be in possession of more than 100 mds. of foodgrains grown in their fields.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Speculative purposive explanation for limited wording.

holdings.text: The presumption under cl. 3(2) does not by itself sustain the prosecution case that the respondent is a dealer under cl. 3(1), hence charge under s.7 ECA not proved.

anchor.surface_text: However that may be, having regard to the words used in cl. 3(2), we are unable to hold that the Judicial Commissioner was wrong in coming to the conclusion that cl. 3(2) by itself would not sustain the prosecution case that the respondent is a dealer under cl. 3(1) and that inevitably means that the charge under s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act is not proved against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of business; presumption insufficient alone.

holdings.text: The order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correct application of law to facts; no proof of dealer/business.

outcome.relief_summary: Order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner upheld; conviction and sentence set aside affirmed as correct

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the point raised by Mr. Khanna before us, it is necessary to bear in mind that clause 3 in question ultimately imposes a penalty on the offender and as such, it is in the nature of a penal clause. Therefore, it is necessary that it must be strictly construed.
That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.
That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.
That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.

anchor.surface_text: GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The short question of law which arises in this appeal relates to the companystruction of cl. 3 2  of the Manipur Foodgrains Dealer

edges.explanation: Principle for interpreting cl. 3(2) deeming provision addresses core construction issue, enabling narrower constitutional reading.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt, as Mr. Khanna has contended, that if cl. 3(2) which is in the nature of a deeming provision provides for a fiction, we ought to draw the fiction to the maximum extent legitimately permissible under the words of the clause.
That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.

edges.explanation: Holding requiring continuity for dealer supports that presumption alone does not prove dealer status

edges.explanation: Holding that dealer requires continuity of transactions addresses the issue on whether business as dealer requires continuity

anchor.surface_text: the concept of business in the context must necessarily postulate continuity of transactions. It is not a single, casual or solitary transaction of sale, purchase or storage that would make a person a dealer. It is only where it is shown that there is a sort of continuity of one or the other of the said transactions that the requirement as to business postulated by the definition would be satisfied.
That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.

anchor.surface_text: What does this presumption amount to? It amounts to this and nothing more that the stock found with a given individual of 100 or more maunds of the specified foodgrains had been stored by him for the purpose of sale. Having reached this conclusion on the strength of the presumption, the prosecution would still have to show that the store of the foodgrains for the purpose of sale thus presumed was made by him for the purpose of carrying on the business
s of his business. Similarly, Form B which prescribes the licence shows that the licence authorises the licence-holder to purchase, sell or store for

anchor.surface_text: The element of business which is essential to attract the provisions of cl. 3(1) is thus not covered by the presumption raised under cl. 3(2). That part of the case would still have to be proved by the prosecution by other independent evidence. It may be that this part of the case can be proved by the prosecution by showing that store of 100 mds. or more of the foodgrains was found with the said person more than once.
That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.

Mr. Khanna contends that in construing the effect of cl. 3(2) we must remember that this clause makes direct reference to cl. 3(1), and that no doubt is true but the fact that cl. 3(2) directly refers to cl. 3(1) does not help to widen the scope of the presumption

edges.explanation: The holding that the charge under s.7 ECA is not proved directly addresses the issue of whether the respondent is guilty under s.7.

anchor.surface_text: However that may be, having regard to the words used in cl. 3(2), we are unable to hold that the Judicial Commissioner was wrong in coming to the conclusion that cl. 3(2) by itself would not sustain the prosecution case that the respondent is a dealer under cl. 3(1) and that inevitably means that the charge under s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act is not proved against him.
That being so, we must hold that the order of acquittal passed by the Judicial Commissioner is right.
